body:
I went through some renaming of package names, in particular python and python3 - as the convention seems to be to add a '3' to the end of the commands (I had submitted an issue to "pip" about them no longer using pip - and the reply was, paraphrased, that "pip" is python2 pip and pip3 is python3 pip.

I have seen a few references to cython3 in posts - but when I pip3 install cython I end with "cython" with the following:

    #!/opt/bin/python3.5
    # EASY-INSTALL-ENTRY-SCRIPT: 'Cython==0.25.1','console_scripts','cython'
    __requires__ = 'Cython==0.25.1'
    import sys
    from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
    
    if __name__ == '__main__':
        sys.exit(
            load_entry_point('Cython==0.25.1', 'console_scripts', 'cython')()
        )

Which is fine - unless you have python2 and python3 installed side-by-side.

I can resort to repackaging tricks (rename the file before building the package) - but pip3 install cython will still be broken.

Or - is cython3 not an issue for you - only for packagers like myself (and others who want to work with python2 and python3 side-by-side)?

comment_data.body: Generally, if you have both python2 and python3, it won't matter which one you use for the cython command (it runs the same in both Python 2 and Python 3, and the produced code is compatible with both).

On 19/11/2016 09:34, Robert Bradshaw wrote:
> Generally, if you have both python2 and python3, it won't matter which one you use for the cython command (it runs the same in both Python 2 and Python 3, and the produced code is compatible with both).
>
Sounds good - "generally" speaking. What might be an indication that 
there is an "exceptional" situation?

For software packaging the issue is that two packages want to own the 
same file - so the second package (generally) ends up owning it. If that 
package gets removed, the file disappears.

However, knowing this, and the names of both packages I can add some 
install logic to test for the other during install and uninstall - and, 
thinking out loud, add or remove a link to cython2 and/or cython3 as 
$prefix/bin/cython.

Thanks for the reply.

However, this is still 'unresolved' for pip(3) install/uninstall.

title: cython and/or cython3 as default name(s) depending on python version loaded
